# Introduction

In the last 40 years after the groundbreaking paper   the theory of quasiperiodic Schrödinger operators has been developed extensively, see the monograph for an overview and for a survey of the more recent results. For shifts on a one-dimensional torus $\mathbb{T}$ most of the results have been established non-perturbatively, i.e., either in the regime of almost reducibility or in the regime of positive Lyapunov exponent, and Avila’s global theory, see , gives a qualitative spectral picture, covering both regimes, for generic potentials. One of the main results of the one-dimensional theory is the fact that the spectrum is a Cantor set. For the case of the almost Mathieu operator (corresponding to a cosine potential), this result has been proved for any non-zero coupling and any irrational shift, see and . For general analytic potentials in the regime of positive Lyapunov exponent with generic shift the Cantor structure of the spectrum has been obtained in .

On the other hand, shifts on a multidimensional torus $\mathbb{T}^d$ turned out to be harder to analyze and the theory is less developed, even in the perturbative setting. In particular, not much is known about the geometry of the spectrum for multidimensional shifts. In their pioneering paper , Chulaevsky and Sinai conjectured that in contrast to the shift on the one-dimensional torus, for the two-dimensional shift the spectrum can be an interval for generic large smooth potentials. In this paper we prove this conjecture for large analytic potentials.

Heuristically, gaps in the spectrum of the one-frequency operators are created by horizontal “forbidden zones” appearing at the points of intersection of the graphs of shifted finite scale eigenvalues parametrized by phase, see . In contrast to this, the heuristic principle underlying is that for multiple frequencies, the intersection curves of the graphs of shifted finite scale eigenvalues may not be too flat, thus preventing the appearance of the horizontal “forbidden zones” and stopping the formation of gaps. It is clear that some genericity assumption on the potential function is needed for this to be true, since potentials like $V(x,y)=v(x)$ lead to flat intersection curves and have Cantor spectrum. Furthermore, the largeness of the potential is also needed. Indeed, it is known that for small potentials with atypical frequency vector the spectrum has gaps, see .

Implementing such an argument, appears to be very challenging for a number of reasons. First, the analytical techniques available in finite volume are less favorable (mainly the large deviation theorems and everything that depends on them) as compared to the case of one frequency. In particular, it is difficult to implement an approach based on finite scale localization as in . This is due to the fact that it is hard to handle long chains of resonances and to control the intersections of the resonant curves with the level sets of the eigenvalues. Second, it is inevitable that the intersection curves of the graphs of shifted finite scale eigenvalues flatten near the absolute extrema and handling this situation seems to be a delicate matter.

We work with operators $$\label{eq:H-lambda} [H_\lambda (x)\psi](n)= -\psi(n+1)-\psi(n-1) + \lambda V(x+n\omega)\psi(n),$$ with $\lambda>0$ being a real parameter, and with the potential $V$ a real analytic function on the torus ${\mathbb T}^d$, $\mathbb{T}={\mathbb R}/{\mathbb Z}$, $d\ge 2$. We assume that the frequency vector $\omega\in \mathbb{T}^d$ obeys the standard Diophantine condition $$\label{eq:vecdiophant} \|k\cdot\omega\|\ge\frac{a}{|k|^{b}}\qquad\text{for all nonzero }k\in{\mathbb Z}^d,$$ where $a>0$, $b>d$ are some constants, $\left\|\cdot\right\|$ denotes the usual norm on ${\mathbb T}$, and $|\cdot|$ denotes the sup-norm on ${\mathbb Z}^d$. Unless otherwise stated, throughout the paper $a,b$ will refer to the constants from [eq:vecdiophant]. In this paper we don’t use elimination of frequencies and our results apply to any Diophantine frequency $\omega$. To simplify notation, we omit dependence on $\omega$ from notation whenever possible. The dependence on frequency will still be reflected by having some of the constants depend on $a,b$.
**Definition 1**. We let $\mathfrak{G}$ be the class of real-analytic functions $V$ on $\mathbb{T}^d$, $d\ge 2$, for which there exist constants $\mathfrak{c}_0=\mathfrak{c}_0(V,d)\in(0,1)$, $\mathfrak{c}_1=\mathfrak{c}_1(d)\in(0,1)$, $\mathfrak{C}_0=\mathfrak{C}_0(V,d)> 1$, such that the following properties hold. \(i\) $V$ is a Morse function, i.e., all its critical points are non-degenerate. \(ii\) $V$ attains each global extremum at just one point.

\(ii\) $V$ attains each global extremum at just one point. \(iii\) Given $h\in \mathbb{T}^d$, let $$g_{V,h,i,j}(x)= \det \begin{bmatrix} \partial_{x_i} V(x) & \partial_{x_j} V(x)\\ \partial_{x_i} V(x+h) & \partial_{x_j} V(x+h) \end{bmatrix}.$$ For any $i\neq j$, $K\ge \mathfrak{C}_0$, and any $\|h\|\ge \exp(-\mathfrak{c}_0K)$ we have $${\rm mes}\{x_{\hat\imath}\in \mathbb{T}^{d-1}: \min_{x_i}\left( |V(x+h)-V(x)|+|g_{V,h,i,j}(x)| \right)<\exp(-K)\}\le \exp(-K^{\mathfrak{c}_1}),$$ where $x_{\hat\imath}=(x_1,\dots,x_{i-1},x_{i+1},\dots,x_d)$. \(iv\) For any $i$, $K\ge \mathfrak{C}_0$, $\eta\in {\mathbb R}$, and $h_0\in {\mathbb R}^d$, $\left\|h_0\right\|=1$, we have $$\begin{gathered} {\rm mes}\{x_{\hat\imath}\in \mathbb{T}^{d-1}:\min_{x_i} \left( |V(x)-\eta|+|\langle \nabla V(x),h_0 \rangle| \right) <\exp(-K)\}\le \exp(-K^{\mathfrak{c}_1}). \end{gathered}$$ Recall that $\mathop{\mathrm{spec}}H_\lambda(x)$ is known not to depend on the phase. Then there exists ${\underline{E}}\in {\mathbb R}$, $|\lambda^{-1}{\underline{E}}-V({\underline{x}})|<\lambda^{-1/4}$, such that $$\subset {\mathcal{S}}_\lambda\quad \text{ and } \quad (-\infty,{\underline{E}})\cap {\mathcal{S}}_\lambda=\emptyset.$$ An analogous statement holds relative to the global maximum of $V$ (using the notation ${\overline{x}},{\overline{E}}$).*

As mentioned above, the derivation of 1 is based on two non-perturbative statements in the regime of positive Lyapunov exponent. Namely, 1 produces an interval in the spectrum in the vicinity of a spectral value at which certain finite scale conditions hold, and 1 shows that the spectrum is an interval under certain additional finite scale conditions. Since the conditions are rather technical, we do not state the theorems here. Their statements can be found in 8. The inductive conditions and their corresponding inductive theorems are discussed in 5 (see 1) and 6 (see 1). In 7 we show how these conditions hold at large coupling, given a potential as in 1. Throughout the paper we will employ the basic tools discussed in 2 for the non-perturbative regime and in 3 for large coupling. The Cartan type estimate that we use to handle the edges of the spectrum is discussed in 4.

Most of the results in this section *do not use* the fact that $V$ assumes only real values on the torus $\mathbb{T}^d$ and therefore they also hold on $\mathbb{T}^d+iy$, $|y|<\rho/2$, by replacing $V$ with $V(\cdot+iy)$. In particular, this applies to all the results up to and including 15. Of course, when we change the potential, we also need to adjust the Lyapunov exponents. To this end we define $$\label{eq:lapyomega} \begin{split} L_N(y,E) &= \frac{1}{N}\int_{\mathbb{T}^d} \log \|M_N(x+iy,E)\|\,dx, \\ L(y,E) &= \lim_{N\to \infty} L_N(y,E). \end{split}$$ We will use some standard conventions. Unless stated otherwise, the constants denoted by $c,C$ might have different values each time they are used. We let $a\lesssim b$ denote $a\le Cb$ with some positive $C$, $a\ll b$ denote $a\le C b$ with a sufficiently large positive $C$, and $a\simeq b$ stand for $a\lesssim b$ and $b\lesssim a$. It will be clear from the context what the implicit constants are allowed to depend on. To emphasize the dependence on some parameter we may use it as a subscript for the above symbols (e.g., $a\simeq_d b$). Our constants will depend on $\omega$, $V$, $E$, $d$, and $\gamma$, where $\gamma>0$ will stand for a lower bound on the Lyapunov exponent. The dependence on $\omega$ will be through the parameters $a,b$ from [eq:vecdiophant]. The dependence on $V$ will be through $\rho$ and $$\left\|V\right\|_\infty:=\sup \{ |V(z)|: z\in \mathbb{T}_{3\rho/4}^d \}.$$ The dependence on $E$ will be uniform on bounded sets. In most cases we leave the dependence on $d$ implicit and, unless stated otherwise, all constants may depend on the dimension $d$.

## Large Deviations Estimates We recall the Large Deviations Theorem (LDT) for the transfer matrix. We refer to and for two different approaches to its proof. The particular formulation we give here is based on (see Corollary 9.2 therein).
**Theorem 3**. *Assume $E\in \mathbb{C}$. There exist $\sigma =\sigma(a,b)$, $\tau=\tau(a,b)$, $\sigma,\tau\in (0,1)$, $C_0=C_0(a,b,\rho)$, such that for $N\ge 1$ one has $${\rm mes}\left\{ x\in{\mathbb T}^d : |\log\|M_N(x,E)\|-NL_N(E)| > C_0S_{V,E}N^{1-\tau} \right\} < \exp(-N^{\sigma}).$$*
In it was shown (see Proposition 2.11 therein) that in the the regime of positive Lyapunov exponent, the large deviations estimate extends to the entries of the transfer matrix.
**Theorem 4**. *Assume $E\in \mathbb{C}$, and $L(E)> \gamma >0$. There exist $\sigma =\sigma(a,b)$, $\tau=\tau(a,b)$, $\sigma,\tau\in (0,1)$, such that for $N\ge N_0(V,a,b,E,\gamma)$ one has $${\rm mes}\left\{ x\in{\mathbb T}^d : |\log |f_N(x,E)|-NL_N(E)| > N^{1-\tau} \right\} < \exp(-N^{\sigma}).$$*
Note that the large deviations estimates also hold with any other smaller choices of the actual exponents $\sigma,\tau$. The sharpness of these exponents plays no role for us, so we will also assume without loss of generality that the exponents are the same in both statements and $\sigma\ll\tau\ll 1$.

This can be achieved through the following result.

**Proposition 6** (). *Assume $E\in \mathbb{C}$, and $L(E)>\gamma>0$. Then for any $N\ge 2$, $$0\le L_N(\omega,E)-L(\omega,E)< C_0\frac{(\log N)^{1/\sigma}}{N}$$ where $C_0=C_0(V,a,b,E,\gamma)$ and $\sigma$ is as in (LDT).*

**Proposition 7** (). *Let $E\in \mathbb{C}$ and $\tau$ as in (LDT). Then for all $N\ge 1$, $$\sup\limits_{x\in{\mathbb T}^d} \log \| M_N (x,E) \| \le NL_N(E)+ C_0 S_{V,E} N^{1-\tau},$$ with $C_0=C_0(a,b,\rho)$.*
To extend the uniform upper estimate to a complex neighborhood of $\mathbb{T}^d$ we need the following result.

**Lemma 8** (). *Let $E\in \mathbb{C}$. For any $N\ge 1$ we have $$|L_N(y,E) - L_N(E)| \le C_\rho S_{V,E}\sum_{i=1}^d |y_i|.$$ In particular, the same bound holds with $L$ instead of $L_N$.*

## Cartan’s Estimate We recall the definition of Cartan sets from . We use the notation ${\mathcal{D}}(z_0,r)=\{ z\in \mathbb{C}: |z-z_0| **Definition 11**. Let $H \ge 1$. For an arbitrary set ${\mathcal{B}}\subset {\mathcal{D}}(z_0, 1)\subset {\mathbb{C}}$ we say that ${\mathcal{B}}\in \mathop{\rm{Car}}\nolimits_1(H, K)$ if ${\mathcal{B}}\subset \bigcup\limits^{j_0}_{j=1} {\mathcal{D}}(z_j, r_j)$ with $j_0 \le K$, and $$\sum_j\, r_j < e^{-H}\ .$$ If $d\ge 1$ is an integer and ${\mathcal{B}}\subset \prod\limits_{j=1}^d {\mathcal{D}}(z_{j,0}, 1)\subset {\mathbb{C}}^d$, then we define inductively that ${\mathcal{B}}\in \mathop{\rm{Car}}\nolimits_d(H, K)$ if for any $1 \le j \le d$ there exists ${\mathcal{B}}_j \subset {\mathcal{D}}(z_{j,0}, 1)\subset {\mathbb{C}}, {\mathcal{B}}_j \in \mathop{\rm{Car}}\nolimits_1(H, K)$ so that ${\mathcal{B}}_z^{(j)} \in \mathop{\rm{Car}}\nolimits_{d-1}(H, K)$ for any $z \in {\mathbb{C}} \setminus {\mathcal{B}}_j$, here ${\mathcal{B}}_z^{(j)} = \left\{(z_1, \dots, z_d) \in {\mathcal{B}}: z_j = z\right\}$. The definition is motivated by the following generalization of the usual Cartan estimate to several variables. Note that given a set $S$ that has a centre of symmetry, we will let $\alpha S$, $\alpha>0$, stand for the set scaled with respect to its centre of symmetry.

**Lemma 12** (). *Let $\varphi(z_1, \dots, z_d)$ be an analytic function defined on a polydisk ${\mathcal{P}}= \prod\limits^d_{j=1} {\mathcal{D}}(z_{j,0}, 1)$, $z_{j,0} \in {\mathbb{C}}$. Let $M \ge \sup\limits_{z\in{\mathcal{P}}} \log |\varphi(z)|$, $m \le \log|\varphi(z_0) |$, $z_0 = (z_{1,0},\dots, z_{d,0})$. Given $H \gg 1$ there exists a set ${\mathcal{B}}\subset {\mathcal{P}}$, ${\mathcal{B}}\in \mathop{\rm{Car}}\nolimits_d\left(H^{1/d}, K\right)$, $K = C_d H(M - m)$, such that $$\label{eq:cart_bd} \log | \varphi(z)| > M-C_d H(M-m)$$ for any $z \in \frac{1}{6}{\mathcal{P}}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}$. Furthermore, when $d=1$ we can take $K=C(M-m)$ and keep only the disks of ${\mathcal{B}}$ containing a zero of $\phi$ in them.*
We note that the definition of the Cartan sets gives implicit information about their measure.
**Lemma 13**. *If ${\mathcal{B}}\in \mbox{\rm Car}_d(H,K)$ then $${\rm mes}_{\mathbb{C}^d}({\mathcal{B}})\le C(d) e^{-H} \text{ and } {\rm mes}_{{\mathbb R}^d}({\mathcal{B}}\cap {\mathbb R}^d)\le C(d) e^{-H}.$$*
*Proof.* The case $d=1$ follows immediately from the definition of $\mbox{\rm Car}_1$. The case $d>1$ follows by induction, using Fubini and the definition of $\mbox{\rm Car}_d$. ◻
The following simple corollary of the Cartan estimate will allow us to upgrade estimates from $\mathbb{T}^d$, where we can take advantage of the fact that $H(x)$ is self-adjoint, to some complex neighborhood of $\mathbb{T}^d$.

**Corollary 14**. *Let $\varphi(z_1, \dots, z_d)$ be an analytic function defined on a polydisk ${\mathcal{P}}= \prod\limits^d_{j=1} {\mathcal{D}}(x_{j,0},1)$, $x_{j,0} \in {\mathbb R}$. Assume $\sup_{\mathcal{P}}\log |\varphi(z)|\le 0$ and $\log |\varphi(x)|\le m<0$ for any $x\in {\mathcal{P}}\cap {\mathbb R}^d$ . Then for any $z\in \frac{1}{24}{\mathcal{P}}$, $$\log |\varphi(z)|< c_0m,$$ with some $c_0\ll_d 1$.*
*Proof.* Assume, to the contrary, that there exists ${z}_0=(z_{j,0})$, $|{z}_0-x_0|<1/24$, such that $\log \bigl |\varphi({z}_0)\bigr |\ge c_0m$, with $c_0$ to be specified later. ## Semialgebraic Sets Recall that a set ${\mathcal{S}}\subset{\mathbb R}^n$ is called semialgebraic if it is a finite union of sets defined by a finite number of polynomial equalities and inequalities. More precisely, a semialgebraic set ${\mathcal{S}}\subset{\mathbb R}^n$ is given by an expression $${\mathcal{S}}=\cup_j \cap_{\ell\in L_j} \{ P_\ell s_{j\ell} 0 \},$$ where $\{P_1,\ldots,P_s\}$ is a collection of polynomials of $n$ variables, $$L_j\subset\{1,\ldots,s\}\text{ and }s_{j\ell}\in\{>,<,=\}.$$ If the degrees of the polynomials are bounded by $d$, then we say that the degree of ${\mathcal{S}}$ is bounded by $sd$. See for more information on semialgebraic sets. In our context, semialgebraic sets can be introduced by approximating the analytic potential $V$ with a polynomial $\tilde V$. More precisely, given $N\ge 1$, by truncating $V$’s Fourier series and the Taylor series of the trigonometric functions, one can obtain a polynomial $\tilde V$ of degree less than $$C(d,\rho)(1+\log \left\|V\right\|_\infty)N^4$$ such that $$\label{eq:V-tilde} \sup_{x\in\mathbb{T}^d}|V(x)-\tilde V(x)|\le \exp(-N^2).$$ If we let $\tilde H$ be the operator with the truncated potential $\tilde V$, we have $$\label{eq:H-tilde} \sup_{x\in \mathbb{T}^d} \left\|H_{[a,b]}(x)-\tilde H_{[a,b]}(x)\right\|\le \exp(-N^2)$$ for any $[a,b]\subseteq {\mathbb Z}$. **Lemma 73**. *If $\left\|\alpha\right\|,\left\|\beta\right\|\ge \exp(-2H)$, then there exists an absolute constant $C_0\gg 1$ such that $$\begin{gathered} {\rm mes}\{ y\in \mathbb{T}: \min_{x}(|V(x+\alpha,y+\beta)-V(x,y)|+|g(x,y,\alpha,\beta)|) <\exp(-C_0H) \}<2\exp(-H/2),\\ {\rm mes}\{ x\in \mathbb{T}: \min_{y}(|V(x+\alpha,y+\beta)-V(x,y)|+|g(x,y,\alpha,\beta)|)<\exp(-C_0H) \}<2\exp(-H/2). \end{gathered}$$*
*Proof.* We only check the first estimate, the second one being completely analogous. Let $$z=\exp(ix),\quad w=\exp(iy),\quad A=\exp(i\alpha),\quad B=\exp(i\beta).$$ Then $$\label{eq:V-g-complexified} V(x+\alpha,y+\beta)-V(x,y)=\frac{1}{2zw} P_1(z,w),\quad g(x,y,\alpha,\beta) =-\frac{1}{4z w } Q_1(z,w),$$ with $$\begin{gathered} P_1(z,w)=(A-1)z^2w+s(B-1)zw^2+(A^{-1}-1)w+s(B^{-1}-1)z,\\ Q_1(z,w)=(B-sA)z^2w^2+(sA-B^{-1})z^2+(sA^{-1}-B)w^2+B^{-1}-sA^{-1}. \end{gathered}$$ Let $a_i$, $b_i$ be the polynomials in $w$ such that $$P_1(z,w)=a_2z^2+a_1z+a_0,\quad Q_1(z,w)=b_2z^2+b_1z+b_0.$$ Let $$R_1(w)=\mathop{\rm{Res}}\nolimits_z (P_1,Q_1)= \det \begin{bmatrix} a_2 & 0 & b_2 & 0\\ a_1 & a_2 & b_1 & b_2\\ a_0 & a_1 & b_0 & b_1\\ 0 & a_0 & 0& b_0 \end{bmatrix}=\sum_{k=0}^8 c_k w^k.$$ Analyzing the degrees of the terms from the Leibniz formula for the above determinant, one sees that the only term containing a monomial of degree $8$ is $$a_1^2 b_2 b_0=[s(B-1)w^2+s(B^{-1}-1)]^2[(B-sA)w^2+sA-B^{-1}][(sA^{-1}-B)w^2+B^{-1}-sA^{-1}],$$ corresponding to the even permutation $$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4\\ 2 & 3 & 1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.$$ It follows that $$c_8=s^2(B-1)^2(B-sA)(sA^{-1}-B)=s^2(B-1)^2(BA^{-1}-s)(s-AB),$$ and therefore $$|c_8|\gtrsim s^2\exp(-4H)|1-|s||^2>\exp(-5H).$$ Then, using 27, $$|R_1(\exp(iy))|\ge \exp(-CH),$$ for $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}_1$, ${\rm mes}({\mathcal{B}}_1)<\exp(-H/2)$, with $C$ an absolute constant. Applying 27 again to $b_2(w)=(B-sA)w^2+sA-B^{-1}$, we get that $$|b_2(\exp(iy))|\ge \exp(-CH),$$ for $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}_2$, ${\rm mes}({\mathcal{B}}_2)<\exp(-H/2)$. At the same time, $$|a_2(\exp(iy))|=|(A-1)\exp(iy)|\gtrsim \exp(-2H),$$ for any $y\in \mathbb{T}$. Let $r(\exp(iy))$ be the maximum of the absolute values of the roots of $P_1(\cdot,\exp(iy))$ and $Q_1(\cdot,\exp(iy))$. Using 26 we have that the $r(\exp(iy)) \le \exp(CH)$, for $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}_2$. Fix $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}$, ${\mathcal{B}}:={\mathcal{B}}_1\cup {\mathcal{B}}_2$. It follows that $$R_1(\exp(iy))\ge 2|a_2(\exp(iy))|^2|b_2(\exp(iy))|^2 r(\exp(iy))^3 \delta,$$ where $\delta=\exp(-CH)$, with $C$ a sufficiently large absolute constant. By 25, $$\max (P_1(z,\exp(iy)),Q_1(z,\exp(iy)))\ge \min(|a_2(\exp(iy))|,|b_2(\exp(iy))|)\delta^2 >\exp(-CH)$$ for any $z$, and therefore $$|V(x+\alpha,y+\beta)-V(x,y)|+|g(x,y,\alpha,\beta)|\ge \exp(-CH),$$ for any $x\in \mathbb{T}$ (recall [eq:V-g-complexified]). The conclusion follows. ◻
Now condition (iii) follows from 72 and 73, by setting $K=C_0H$, with $C_0$ as in 73, and by taking $\mathfrak{c}_0=1/C_0$, $\mathfrak{c}_1=1/2$, $$\label{eq:fC0} \mathfrak{C}_0=C(C_0^2+C_0\max(\log |s|,\log |s|^{-1},\log |1-s^2|^{-1})),\quad C\gg 1.$$ Finally, we check that condition (iv) holds for $s\notin \{ -1,0,1 \}$. Take $H$ as in [eq:H-lb], $\eta\in {\mathbb R}$, and $h_0\in {\mathbb R}^2$ a unit vector. With some abuse of notations we let $h_0=(\alpha,\beta)$, $\alpha^2+\beta^2=1$.
**Lemma 74**. *(a) If $|\alpha|<\exp(-2H)$, then $${\rm mes}\{ y\in \mathbb{T}: \min_{x} |\langle \nabla V(x,y),h_0 \rangle|< \exp(-2H)\}<\exp(-H).$$ (b) If $|\beta|<\exp(-2H)$, then $${\rm mes}\{ x\in \mathbb{T}: \min_{y} |\langle \nabla V(x,y),h_0 \rangle|< \exp(-2H)\}<\exp(-H).$$*
*Proof.* (a) Since $|\alpha|<\exp(-2H)$, we have $|\beta|\ge (1-\exp(-4H))^{1/2}>1/2$, and therefore $$|\langle \nabla V(x,y),h_0 \rangle|=|\alpha \sin x+s\beta \sin y| \ge \frac{1}{2}s\sin y-\exp(-2H)\ge \exp(-2H),$$ for all $x\in \mathbb{T}$, and $y$ such that $|\sin y|>\exp(-3H/2)$. The conclusion follows. The proof for (b) is analogous. ◻
**Lemma 75**. *(a) If $|\alpha|\ge \exp(-2H)$, then there exists an absolute constant $C_0\gg 1$ such that $${\rm mes}\{ y\in \mathbb{T}: \min_{x} (|V(x,y)-\eta|+|\langle \nabla V(x,y),h_0 \rangle|) < \exp(-C_0H)\}<\exp(-H/2).$$ (b) If $|\beta|\ge \exp(-2H)$, then there exists an absolute constant $C_0\gg 1$ such that $${\rm mes}\{ x\in \mathbb{T}: \min_{y}(|V(x,y)-\eta|+|\langle \nabla V(x,y),h_0 \rangle|)< \exp(-C_0H)\} <\exp(-H/2).$$*
*Proof.* We only prove (a), the proof of the second statement being analogous. By letting $z=\exp(ix)$, $w=\exp(iy)$, we have $$\label{eq:V-eta-complexified} V(x,y)-\eta=\frac{1}{2zw} P_2(z,w),\quad \langle \nabla V(x,y),h_0 \rangle=-\frac{1}{2izw} Q_2(z,w),$$ with $$\begin{gathered} P_2(z,w)=z^2w+szw^2-2\eta zw+w+sz,\\ Q_2(z,w)=\alpha z^2 w+\beta zw^2-\alpha w-\beta z. \end{gathered}$$ Let $a_i$, $b_i$ be the polynomials in $w$ such that $$P_2(z,w)=a_2z^2+a_1z+a_0,\quad Q_2(z,w)=b_2z^2+b_1z+b_0.$$ In particular, $a_2(w)=w$ and $b_2(w)=\alpha w$. A direct computation yields $$\begin{gathered} R_2(w)=\mathop{\rm{Res}}\nolimits_z(P_2,Q_2)=\sum_{k=0}^6 c_kw^k\\ \kern-20em=w^{6} \left(- \alpha^{2} s^{2} + \beta^{2}\right) +w^{5} (4 \alpha^{2} \eta s) \\ + w^{4} \left(- 4 \alpha^{2} \eta^{2} - 2 \alpha^{2} s^{2} + 4 \alpha^{2} - 2 \beta^{2}\right) + w^{3}(4 \alpha^{2} \eta s) + w^{2} \left(- \alpha^{2} s^{2} + \beta^{2}\right)\\ \kern-10em =w^{6} \left(1- \alpha^{2} (1+s^{2}) \right) +w^{5} (4 \alpha^{2} \eta s) \\ + w^{4}\left(\alpha^2(6-4\eta^2-2s^2)-2\right) + w^{3}(4 \alpha^{2} \eta s) + w^{2} \left(1- \alpha^{2}(1+ s^{2}) \right). \end{gathered}$$ We will argue that not all of the coefficients of $R_2$ are too small. To this end, note that $$2\alpha^{-2}c_6+\alpha^{-2}c_4=4-4s^2-4\eta^2.$$ If $|\eta|<\exp(-H)$, then $$|2\alpha^{-2}c_6+\alpha^{-2}c_4|>4|1-s^2|-4\exp(-2H)>2|1-s^2|>\exp(-H),$$ and therefore, either $$|c_6|\gtrsim \exp(-H)\alpha^2\ge \exp(-5H) \qquad\text{or}\qquad |c_4|\gtrsim \exp(-H)\alpha^2 \ge \exp(-5H).$$ On the other hand, if $|\eta|\ge \exp(-H)$, then $$|c_5|\gtrsim \alpha^2\exp(-H)s>\exp(-6H).$$ Thus, $\max_{k}|c_k|\gtrsim \exp(-6H)$. Then, using 27, $$|R_2(\exp(iy))|\ge \exp(-CH),$$ for $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}$, ${\rm mes}({\mathcal{B}})<\exp(-H/2)$. Let $r(\exp(iy))$ be the maximum of the absolute values of the roots of $P_2(\cdot,\exp(iy))$ and $Q_2(\cdot,\exp(iy))$. By 26, $r(\exp(iy))<\exp(3H)$. Then $$|R_2(\exp(iy))|\ge 2|a_2(\exp(iy))|^2|b_2(\exp(iy))|^2 r(\exp(iy))^3\delta,$$ for $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}$, with $\delta=\exp(-CH)$. By 25, $$\max(P_2(z,\exp(iy)),Q_2(z,\exp(iy)))\ge \min(|a_2(\exp(iy))|,|b_2(\exp(iy))|)\delta^2>\exp(-CH)$$ for any $z$, and $y\in \mathbb{T}\setminus {\mathcal{B}}$. The conclusion follows by recalling [eq:V-eta-complexified]. ◻
Now condition (iv) follows from 74 and 75, by setting $K=C_0H$, with $C_0$ as in 75, and by taking $\mathfrak{c}_1=1/2$ and $\mathfrak{C}_0$ as in [eq:fC0], with the new $C_0$. Obviously, we can arrange for both condition (iii) and (iv) to hold with the same $\mathfrak{C}_0$.
*Remark 76*. (a) It should be clear that for $s\in \{ -1,0,1 \}$ not all of the conditions are satisfied. Indeed, we noted that conditions (i) and (ii) fail for $s=0$, and for $s=\pm 1$, for example, condition (iv) fails for $\eta=0$ and $h_0$ proportional to $(\pm 1,1)$. \(b\) Due to the choices of $\mathfrak{C}_0$ in [eq:fC0] and $\lambda_0$ implied by the proof of 1 (recall [eq:TV-final]), we have that as $s$ approaches $\{ -1,0,1 \}$, $\lambda_0$ approaches $\infty$, as claimed in 2 (c).
